translated: The Elder Nuns’ Verses of the Therīs🔽The Group of Eights
The Elder Nun Paṭācārā’s Verses
“The Victor Padumuttara,

analyzed: sabba dhammāna pāragū  i taḥ sata sahassamhi
translated: who had gone beyond all things,🔽appeared as a Leader
a hundred thousand eons ago.

analyzed: tadā aham  jātā seṭṭhi kule ahu
translated: Then I was born in Haṁsavati,🔽in a leading family,
with a lamp of various jewels,
endowed with great happiness.
Having approached that Great Hero,
I listened to the teaching of the Dhamma;
Then, with confidence arisen,
I went for refuge to the Victor.
Then the Leader praised
the foremost of those who uphold the Monastic Law,
the nun Lājī, who was so modest,
skilled in the rules, and so forth.
Then, with a mind of joy,🔽desiring that state,🔽having invited the One of Ten Powers,

analyzed: tam ṭhānam abhikaṅkhinī  dasabala  sa saṅgham lokanāyaka  bhojayitvāna sattā āha
translated: the Leader of the World, with the Community of monks,🔽having fed them for seven days,
and given them three robes,

analyzed: nipad ca sirasā pāde  idam vacanam abravi
translated: I respectfully touched my head🔽to their feet and spoke this verse:
‘You who are praised by the Hero,
in the eighth future Buddha,
I will be like that,
if it is possible, Leader.’
Then the Teacher said to me,
‘Blessed One, do not be afraid, take heart!
In the future time,
you will fulfill that wish.
After a hundred thousand aeons,
in the lineage of the crow-eater,
in the Gotama family,
there will be a teacher in the world.
His heirs in the Dhamma,
with the Dhamma as their essence,
will be called Paṭācārā,
the disciple of the Teacher.’
Then I, being joyful,
for as long as I lived,
with a mind of loving-kindness, served
the Leader of the world, with his Saṅgha.
By that well-done deed,
by the intention and aspiration,
having given up the human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
In this auspicious aeon,
the kinsman of Brahmā, of great fame,
in the Kassapa family,
the best of speakers arose.
The supporter of the Great Seer,
then was the lord of men,
the King of Kāsi, named Kikī,
in the supreme city of Bārāṇasī.
I was his third daughter,
well-known as the nun,
having heard the Victor’s Dhamma,
I delighted in the going forth.
Our father did not give his permission,
so we remained in the house.
For twenty-thousand years,
we roamed about diligently.
The youthful spiritual life,
the royal daughters well-nourished;
Devoted to serving the Buddha,
the seven sisters were joyful.
The ascetic, the one with the ascetic’s staff,
the nun, the one who gives to the monks;

analyzed: dhammā ca iva su dhammā ca
translated: Dhammā and Sudhammā,
the seventh was the one who gave to the Sangha.
Uppalavaṇṇā and I,
Khemā and the nun Bhaddā;
Kisāgotamī and Dhammadinnā,
and the seventh was Visākhā.
By those well-done deeds,
by intentions and aspirations;
Having abandoned the human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
And in my last birth,
I was born into a merchant family;
In Sāvatthī, the best of cities,
prosperous, wealthy, and very rich.
When I was in my youth,
I was under the sway of thoughts.
Seeing a man who had aged,
I went with him.
I had a son, and I was pregnant with a second child.
Then my parents,
I said, “I give permission,” and was sure.
I did not tell my husband,
at that time, when I was purified;
Alone, I left the house,
to go to the supreme city of Sāvatthī.
Then my husband came,
and on the road he met me;
At that time, winds from my karma
arose, extremely terrible.
And a great cloud arose,
at the time of my delivery;
Then, going for water,
my husband was killed by a snake.
Then, suffering from childbirth,
helpless and miserable,
seeing the Kunnadi pool full,
I went to the Sakulan home.
Carrying my child, I crossed,
and on the far bank, alone;
Having left the little child,

analyzed: itaram taraṇāya ha  nivattā ukkusaḥ hāsi
translated: for the sake of crossing, I went on.🔽The she-parrot turned back, laughing,
the young one crying;
And the other, the current,
I, overcome with grief.
Going to the city of Sāvatthī,
I heard that many people had died;
Then I spoke, in a state of grief,
overcome with great sorrow.
‘Both my children have died,
and on the road my husband died;
Mother, father, and brother,
I was burning with one thought.’
Then I was thin and pale,
helpless and miserable;
Wandering here and there,
I saw the Charioteer of Men.
Then the Teacher said to me,
‘Do not grieve for your children, take heart!
Search for yourself,
why do you torment yourself for nothing?
There are no children to be a refuge,
no relatives or kinsmen;
When overcome by the End-maker,
there is no protection in relatives.’
Having heard the Sage’s words,
first the fruit of the middle stage;
Having gone forth not long after,
I attained Liberation.
I became powerful in psychic abilities,
with the divine ear-element;
I knew the minds of others,
I fulfilled the Teacher’s instruction.
I knew my past lives,
the divine eye was purified;
Having expelled all the pollutants,
I was purified, stainless.
Then I learned all the Monastic Law,
in the presence of the All-Seeing One;
I learned it in all its detail,
and I recited it as it truly is.
The Victorious One, pleased with that quality,
placed me at the head of the list,
‘Foremost among those who uphold the Monastic Law,
Paṭācārā is alone.’
I have attended on the Teacher,
I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
The heavy burden is laid down,
the fetters that bound me to existence are destroyed.
The purpose for which I went forth
from the home to the homeless life
has now been accomplished:
the destruction of all fetters.
My defilements are ended,
I live undefiled.
Welcome indeed it was for me
I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
The four analytical knowledges

translated: I have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.”🔽This is what Venerable Paṭācārā said,🔽The backstory of Venerable Paṭācārā is the tenth.
The second sub-chapter on the nun who was a one-day fasting practitioner is finished.🔽The summary:
The one-day fasting practitioner,
and the six, and the sweet balls,
the one meal a day, the five lights,
the garland of reeds, and Gotamī.
Khemā, and Uppalavaṇṇā,
and the nun Paṭācārā;
Five hundred and nine
verses, and more besides.
